Name: Citronellol
Description: Citronellol is a monoterpenoid that is oct-6-ene substituted by a hydroxy group at position 1 and methyl groups at positions 3 and 7. It has a role as a plant metabolite.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Fahlbusch KG et al; Flavors and Fragrances. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 7th ed. (1999-2015). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: Jan 15, 2003. (2) Burdock GA ed; Fenaroli's Handbook of Flavor Ingredients. 6th ed. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press, p. 316 (2010) (3) Koukos PK et al; J Agric Food Chem 48: 1266-68 (2000) (4) Schlotzhauer WS et al; J Agric Food Chem 44: 206-9 (1996) (5) Rodgman A, Perfetti TA; The Chemical Components of Tobacco and Tobacco Smoke, 2nd edition. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press, Taylor & Francis Group, p. 2079 (2013) (6) Verma RS et al; Nat Prod Res 25(17): 1577-84 (2011)
plant_concentrations.Value: (+)-Citronellol occurs in natural oils from Boronia citriodora (total citronellol content about 80%) and Eucalyptus citriodora (total citronellol content 15-20%)(1); (-)-Citronellol is the predominant enantiomer in geranium and rose oils, both of which may contain up to 50% citronellols(1). Citronellol has reported to occur in about 70 essential oils(2). It reportedly occurs in guava fruit, orange, bilberry, blackcurrant, nutmeg, ginger, corn, mint oil, mustard, hop oil, tea, coriander seed, and cardamom(2). Essential oils from twigs and needles of the Balkan pine (Pinus peuce Gris.) grown in northern Greece was found to contain citronellol in the twig oil (12.48% of total) and needle oil (13.42% of total)(3). Trace concentrations of citronellol (<20 ug/kg) were detected in the flowers of Japan honeysuckle (Lonicera japonica)(4). Citronellol has been detected in tobacco(5). The essential oil of rose water, derived from Rosa damascena Mill. from northern India, contained citronellol at concentrations of 15.9-35.3%(6).
